conclusion: The problem involves finding the electric field strength in a uniform electric field where a small charged ball is in equilibrium, suspended by a string at an angle.
The forces acting on the ball are identified as gravitational force (mg), tension in the string (T), and electric force (qE).
The condition for equilibrium is that the vector sum of all forces acting on the ball must be zero.
The gravitational force (mg) acts vertically downward.
The electric force (qE) acts horizontally to the right.
The tension (T) in the string has both horizontal and vertical components: T cos θ (horizontal) and T sin θ (vertical).
The horizontal components of the forces must balance: T cos θ = qE.
The vertical components of the forces must balance: T sin θ = mg.
From the horizontal direction equation T cos θ = qE, solve for T: T = qE / cos θ.
Substitute T = qE / cos θ into the vertical direction equation T sin θ = mg.
Simplify the equation (qE / cos θ) sin θ = mg to qE tan θ = mg.
Solve for E: E = mg / (q tan θ).
The electric field strength E is determined to be mg / (q tan θ).
